text: Practice Problem 2.10 (solution page 182) As an application of the property that a ” a = 0 for any bit vector a, consider the following program: 1 void inplace_swap(int +x, int +y) { 2 g = 5x 7 xY; /+ Step 1 %/ 3 x= 5x 7 xy; /+ Step 2 %/ 4 *y = 5x 7 4y; /% Step 3 +/ 5s 3) As the name implies, we claim that the effect of this procedure is to swap the values stored at the locations denoted by pointer variables x and y. Note that unlike the usual technique for swapping two values, we do not need a third location to temporarily store one value while we are moving the other. There is no performance advantage to this way of swapping; it is merely an intellectual amusement. Starting with values a and b in the locations pointed to by x and y, respectively, fill in the table that follows, giving the values stored at the two locations after each step of the procedure. Use the properties of ” to show that the desired effect is achicved. Recall that cvery clement is its own additive inverse (that is, a ” a = 0). Step *x y Initially a b Step 1 Step2 Step3
